Interest of 1½ percent shall be assessed for each month or fraction thereof that the tax and/or fee remains delinquent after the imposition of the ten percent penalty. (c)  A business registration certificate shall be issued by the city finance department for each registration under this article. The business registration certificate shall be prominently displayed in each office of the business in the city. If any person, firm or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a business registration certificate shall, after the registration and occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact business in the city, such offender shall, in addition to remedies provided herein, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8. (Code 1989, § 12-29.11; Ord. No. 355, § 11, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 11, 8-28-1995; Ord. No. 593, § 1(exh. A), 6-19-2006) 
Sec. 42-66. - Allocation of employees of business with multiple intrastate or interstate locations.     For those businesses having multiple locations inside and outside the city, only the employees who work in the city locations will be counted for occupation tax purposes. (Code 1989, § 12-29.12; Ord. No. 355, § 12, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 12, 8-28-1995; Ord. No. 593, § 1(exh. A), 6-19-2006) 
Sec. 42-67. - Exemption for state and local authorities and nonprofit organizations.     State and local authorities and nonprofit organizations are exempt from any occupation tax, regulatory fee or administrative fee levied pursuant to this article. (Code 1989, § 12-29.13; Ord. No. 355, § 13, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 13, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-68. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed.     Each person required to be licensed under title 43 of the state license examining boards shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration may be issued. (Code 1989, § 12-29.14; Ord. No. 355, § 14, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 14, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-69. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. (a)  Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, certificates of occupancy or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence of such qualification. (b)  Any business required to submit an annual application for continuance of that business shall do so before the registration is issued. (Code 1989, § 12-29.15; Ord. No. 355, § 15, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 15, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-70. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain.     All persons subject to the occupation taxes provided in this article shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for such business as provided in this article, and in default thereof, the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a certificate. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration before commencing the same; and any person transacting or offering to transact in the city any of the kinds of business, trade, profession or occupation without first having so obtained such registration shall be subject to penalties provided herein, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. (Code 1989, § 12-29.16; Ord. No. 355, § 16, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 16, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-71. - City building official; business inspector.     The city code enforcement manager and his duly designated officers and inspectors or his successors shall be classified as deputy officer business inspector with full subpoena and arresting powers in conjunction with any violation pertaining to the business tax ordinance for 1995 and succeeding years thereafter. (Code 1989, § 12-29.18; Ord. No. 355, § 18, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 18, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-72. - Businesses not covered by this article.     The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article, but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by act of local law: (1)  Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission. (2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. title 46, ch. 3. (3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. (4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-80 et seq. (5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8. (6)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (7)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. (8)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. (9)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. (Code 1989, § 12-29.19; Ord. No. 355, § 19, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 19, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-73. - Occupation tax inapplicable where prohibited by law or provided for pursuant to other existing law.     This occupation tax is not levied upon any business or any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of the state or of the United States. (Code 1989, § 12-29.20; Ord. No. 355, § 20, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 20, 8-28-1995; Ord. No. 593, § 1(exh. A), 6-19-2006) 
Sec. 42-74. - More than one place or line of business.     Where a business is operated at more than one place or where the business includes more than one line, the number of employees at each location will be entered on a separate occupation tax return and the tax will be calculated at the rate of the dominant line of business conducted by the business, identified on a form to be furnished by the city. (Code 1989, § 12-29.21; Ord. No. 355, § 21, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 21, 8-28-1995; Ord. No. 593, § 1(exh. A), 6-19-2006) 
Sec. 42-75. - Returns confidential.     Except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the occupation tax hereby levied, the contents of occupation tax returns shall be confidential and open only to the officials, employees, agents or clerks of the city using said returns for the purpose of this occupation tax levy and the collection of the tax. Independent auditors or bookkeepers employed by the city shall be classed as employees. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the publication by the city of statistics, so classified as to reasonably prevent the identification of particular reports or returns and items thereof, or the inspection of the records by duly qualified employees of the tax departments of the state or of the United States, and other local governments. Information provided by a business or practitioner may also be disclosed to the governing authority of another local government for occupational tax purposes. (Code 1989, § 12-29.22; Ord. No. 355, § 22, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 22, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-76. - Inspection of books and records.     In any case, the finance department of the city, through its officers, agents, employees or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which the returns are made. The director of the finance department or the director's designee shall have the right to inspect the books or records for the business of which the return was made in the city, and upon demand of the director of the finance department or the director's designee, such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within 30 days. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax certificate currently existing to do business in the city. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the director of the finance department or the director's designee at the director's discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty of ten percent of the deficiency and an additional one percent of the deficiency for each month or fraction thereof that the deficiency was due and unpaid shall be assessed. (Code 1989, § 12-29.23; Ord. No. 355, § 23, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 23, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-77. - Business registration certificate to be revoked for failure to pay tax, file returns, or permit inspection of books.     Except for a person whose qualifications to practice his profession are determined by the general laws of the state, upon the failure of any business to pay such occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as above provided, any business registration certificate granted by the city under this article permitting the owner of such business to do business in the city for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business registration certificate shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax herein provided for is at that time unpaid, or to a person who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the finance department in accordance with provisions found in section 42-76. (Code 1989, § 12-29.24; Ord. No. 355, § 24, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 24, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-78. - Effect of failure to comply with article provisions; continuing in business after business registration certificate revocation.     Any person, their manager, agent or employee, who does business in the city after the certificate for such business has been revoked as above; any person, their manager, agent or employee, hereby required to make returns showing the number of employees, and who fails to make such returns within the time and in the manner herein provided, or refuses to amend such returns so as to set forth the correct information, or who shall make false returns; and any person, their manager, agent or employee who refuses to permit an inspection of books in his charge when the officer, agent, employee or representative of the city requests such inspection, during business hours, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns herein provided for, shall be subject to penalties provided in section 1-8. (Code 1989, § 12-29.25; Ord. No. 355, § 25, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 25, 8-28-1995; Ord. No. 593, § 1(exh. A), 6-19-2006) 
Sec. 42-79. - Execution for delinquent occupation tax.     In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the director of the finance department of the city, upon any tax or installment of such tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of such tax against the person liable for such tax, which execution shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property of the person liable for such tax, all as provided by the ordinances and Charter of the city and the laws of the state. The lien of such occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the director of the finance department of the city upon the property of the person liable for such tax, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of such execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by the ordinances and the Charter of the city and the laws of the state, and the defendant in such execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the Charter of the city and the laws of the state in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the city against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest, penalties and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due the person as though the person had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. (Code 1989, § 12-29.26; Ord. No. 355, § 26, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 26, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-80. - Amendment or repeal of provision.     This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the city of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property or business. (Code 1989, § 12-29.27; Ord. No. 355, § 27, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 27, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-81. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance.     This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee or assessment shall be fully paid. (Code 1989, § 12-29.28; Ord. No. 355, § 28, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 28, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-82. - Enforcement of provisions.     It is hereby made the duty of the building official, the finance department and the police department to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed, and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the municipal court. It is hereby made the further duty of the building official, director of the finance department, the chief of police and their designees and assistants to inspect all certificates issued by the city, as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the certificate held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. (Code 1989, § 12-29.29; Ord. No. 355, § 29, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 29, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-83. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by council.     This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the council. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. (Code 1989, § 12-29.30; Ord. No. 355, § 30, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 30, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-84. - Requirement of public hearing before tax increase.     The council shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. (Code 1989, § 12-29.31; Ord. No. 355, § 31, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 31, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-85. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax.     The council may, by this article or subsequent ordinance or resolution, provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions or to a designated district as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Any such plan may be designed to attract development to a particular area in the city or to the city at large. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious. (Code 1989, § 12-29.32; Ord. No. 355, § 32, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 32, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-86. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions.     Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. (Code 1989, § 12-29.33; Ord. No. 355, § 33, 12-20-1994; Ord. No. 366, § 33, 8-28-1995) 
Sec. 42-87. - Information provided to state department of revenue. (a)  Any person who performs any business, occupation or profession subject to an occupation tax or regulatory fee under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq. is required to provide the city the following information when paying such occupation tax or regulatory fee: (1)  The legal name of the business; (2)  Any associated trade names for the business; (3)  The mailing address for the business; (4)  The actual physical address of each location of the business, if it is different than the mailing address; (5)  The North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code applicable to such business; and (6)  The sales and use tax identification number assigned to the business by the state department of revenue, if the business is required by law to have such a number. (b)  The city will provide written notice to all persons subject to the city's occupation taxes or regulatory fees that: (1)  This information will be provided to the state department of revenue; and (2)  If the person refuses or fails to provide the required information, the city will notify the state department of revenue of this fact. (c)  Within 30 days after receiving the payment of occupation taxes or regulatory fees pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-20, or at such other later date as otherwise reasonable, the city will electronically submit the information received from each business to the state department of revenue. (Code 1989, § 12-29.34; Res. No. 1535, 2-21-2011) 
Secs. 42-88—42-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AD VALOREM TAX[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(a) and (b)(2); ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal power of ad valorem taxation to provide for financial assistance to its development authority, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq. 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
Sec. 42-120. - Ad valorem tax due and delinquency dates; penalties.     Citizens of the city are hereby given the following deadline for filing and paying their property taxes: (1)  All property owners, both real and personal, shall declare their taxable properties in accordance with the rules and regulations provided for by the county tax assessor and the state property tax division. The city shall levy and collect ad valorem taxes based upon tax records provided by the county. These records shall include, but not be limited to, the owner's name, address, property assessment, valuation, and exemptions (if any). (2)  Ad valorem taxes will be billed on or about October 1 of each year for that tax year, and shall be payable within 60 days of the bill date. Any ad valorem taxes due under the provisions of this section shall bear interest at the maximum rate allowed by state law. Additionally, a penalty shall be imposed on any unpaid principal in accordance with state law. (3)  Unpaid accounts shall be delinquent 30 days after the due date and shall be subject to late notices, publication of owners' names within the legal organ for the city, and execution of fi. fas. (4)  The ad valorem tax rate for the city for the 2015 calendar year, on property subject to ad valorem taxation by the city, is hereby fixed at $5.750 on 40 percent of each $1,000.00 of property subject to ad valorem tax by the city. (5)  Said rate of $5.750 on 40 percent of each $1,000.00 of taxable property is hereby levied as follows: a.  For general government purposes: $5.000 on 40 percent of each $1,000.00 of taxable property. b.  For the purpose of retiring outstanding general obligation bonds: $0.7500 on 40 percent of each $1,000.00 of taxable property. (Code 1989, § 8-51; Ord. No. 101, 11-8-1966; Ord. No. 457, § 1, 12-18-2000; Ord. No. 706, §§ I, II, 7-20-2015) State Law reference— O.C.G.A. § 48-2-44. 
Secs. 42-121—42-138. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TAX EXECUTIONS AND SALES 
Sec. 42-139. - Municipal tax collector. (a)  Creation of office. There is hereby created in the city the office of municipal tax collector. This office shall be held by the city administrator who shall be responsible for carrying out the provisions of this division. The municipal tax collector shall also undertake such duties as prescribed, from time to time, by the mayor and council. (b)  Additional powers and authority. The municipal tax collector shall have such further powers and authority as is necessary to carry out the requirements of this division. (Code 1989, § 8-61; Ord. No. 263, §§ 1, 22, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-140. - Records to be kept by municipal tax collector.     The municipal tax collector or his designee shall maintain the following records in carrying out the provisions of this division: (1)  Defaulters book. The municipal tax collector shall prepare and maintain a book listing all defaulters (delinquent taxpayers) and the amount and value of the property in default. (2)  Execution docket. The municipal tax collector shall maintain an execution docket listing the executions against all delinquent taxpayers by entering their names in the docket along with an itemized statement of the taxes covered by the executions. (Code 1989, § 8-62; Ord. No. 263, § 2, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-141. - Issuance, direction and recording of tax executions.     Where any property owner who has property subject to taxation within the limits of the city shall fail, refuse or neglect to pay the taxes imposed according to law or the ordinances of the city, the municipal tax collector is hereby authorized to issue an execution against the property owner for the tax, which execution shall bear interest in the name of the city, be entered on the records of the municipal tax collector, and be directed to the chief of police, commanding him to levy on the personal and real property of the property owner, or so much thereof as shall be sufficient to satisfy the demand and costs. Upon issuance of the execution, the municipal tax collector shall also be authorized to record the execution on the general execution docket in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county. (Code 1989, § 8-63; Ord. No. 263, § 3, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-142. - Date of issuance; enforcement of executions.     At any time after the last day for the payment of taxes has arrived, the municipal tax collector may notify, in writing, each delinquent taxpayer of the fact that the taxes owing have not been paid, and that, unless paid, an execution shall be issued. The municipal tax collector may issue executions for nonpayment of taxes collectable at any time after 30 days have elapsed since giving the foregoing notice. The execution shall include the owner of the property to which the execution is directed, the year for which the execution is to be issued, a description of the property sufficient to put interested parties on notice as to where the subject property can be located, the amount due including the tax, penalties, execution costs, and interest, the name of the officer conducting the levy and his address, the date the execution was issued, and the official who issued the tax execution. Such tax executions shall be levied and collected as provided by this division and state law. (Code 1989, § 8-64; Ord. No. 263, § 4, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-143. - City's costs and fees on executions.     The costs and fees of the city on executions shall be as follows: the costs and fees associated with the collection of delinquent tax accounts including the execution of fi. fas, settling fi. fas, advertising, and any reasonable collection costs shall be added to the delinquent tax account at the actual proportionate cost paid by the city, with relation to each delinquent tax account. (Code 1989, § 8-65; Ord. No. 263, § 5, 10-23-1989; Ord. No. 457, § 2, 12-18-2000) 
Sec. 42-144. - Alias tax executions.     When a properly issued tax execution is lost or destroyed, an alias tax execution may be issued by the municipal tax collector, and such alias tax execution shall have the same force and effect as the lost or destroyed original execution. (Code 1989, § 8-66; Ord. No. 263, § 6, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-145. - Interest on executions.     All taxes, from the date the same become delinquent and in default, and all penalties and other sums owing under executions, from the date of imposition, shall bear interest from such dates as provided by state law. (Code 1989, § 8-67; Ord. No. 263, § 7, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-146. - Procedures for sales under tax executions.     The property which is the subject of the tax execution shall be advertised and sold as provided by state law for fi. fas and judicial sales, with the exception that the place of sale shall be held in the council chambers of the city. In addition to the notice required under state law, at any sale under tax execution under this division, the defendant in fi. fa shall be given 20 days' written notice of such sale by registered mail to the last-known address as listed in the records of the municipal tax collector. (Code 1989, § 8-68; Ord. No. 263, § 8, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-147. - Duty of levying officers.     The municipal tax collector shall place issued executions in the hands of the city police chief or his designee, who shall be authorized to collect or levy the executions as provided herein. The levying officer shall proceed promptly to enforce by levy and sale the collection of the executions. The levying or collecting officer shall make prompt settlements with the municipal tax collector and return to the municipal tax collector the tax collected and the uncollected executions with proper entries on the executions. (Code 1989, § 8-69; Ord. No. 263, § 9, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-148. - Failure to find property on which to levy.     When the levying officer can find no property belonging to the taxpayer on which to levy, the officer shall place such notation (nulla bona) on the execution and return it to the municipal tax collector. Upon the return of the execution, the city may proceed with the issuance of a summons of garnishment as well as such other remedies as provided under state law. (Code 1989, § 8-70; Ord. No. 263, § 10, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-149. - Payment of excess.     Any excess remaining after the payment of taxes, costs and all expenses of a sale shall be immediately paid to the person authorized to receive the excess. (Code 1989, § 8-71; Ord. No. 263, § 11, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-150. - Authority of levying officer to put purchaser in possession of land.     The officer selling property at a tax sale shall have the authority, subject to requirements of state law, to put purchasers in possession of land sold under tax executions. (Code 1989, § 8-72; Ord. No. 263, § 12, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-151. - Purchase of property by city.     The city may purchase and hold in its official capacity any real or personal property offered for sale by virtue of tax executions, except that the city may bid on such property only when other bids do not cover the amount of the tax execution and related costs. The city shall not bid more for the property than the amount of taxes, interest, penalties and costs due. (Code 1989, § 8-73; Ord. No. 263, § 13, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-152. - Register to be kept showing land sold for taxes and redemption.     The municipal tax collector shall keep a register of all sales of real estate, whether vacant or improved, in a book provided for that purpose, in which the municipal tax collector shall enter each tract or lot of land sold, the precise quantity sold, a copy of the advertisement, the amount of taxes and costs the property was sold for and the purchaser's name. Space shall also be provided to insert the name of the person who may redeem such lot or tract of land, the date of redemption and the amount of redemption money paid. (Code 1989, § 8-74; Ord. No. 263, § 14, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-153. - Persons entitled to redeem land sold under tax execution; payment; time.     Whenever any real property is sold under or by virtue of an execution issued for the collection of ad valorem taxes, the defendant in fi. fa or any person having any right, title or interest in or lien upon such property may redeem the property from the sale by the payment of the redemption price as provided in section 42-154: (1)  At any time within 12 months from the date of the sale; and (2)  At any time after the sale until the right to redeem is foreclosed by the giving of the notice provided for in section 42-157. (Code 1989, § 8-75; Ord. No. 263, § 15, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-154. - Amount payable for redemption. (a)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section, the amount required to be paid for redemption of property from any sale for taxes as provided in this division (the "redemption price") shall be the amount paid for the property at the tax sale, as shown by the recitals in the tax deed, plus any taxes paid on the property by the purchaser after the sale for taxes, plus a premium of ten percent of the amount for each year or fraction of a year which has elapsed between the date of the sale and the date on which the redemption payment is made. If redemption is not made until after the required notice of foreclosure of right to redeem has been given, there shall be added to the redemption price the cost of serving the notice, the cost of publication of the notice, if any, and the sum of ten percent of the amount paid for the property at the sale to cover the cost of making the necessary examinations to determine the person upon whom notice should be served. All amounts required to be paid hereunder shall be paid to the purchaser at the tax sale or to his successors. (b)  In cases where the city purchases property at a tax sale, the redemption price shall be the amount paid for the property at the tax sale, as shown by the recitals in the tax deed, plus a premium of 20 percent of the amount for each year or fraction of a year which has elapsed between the date of the sale and the date on which the redemption payment is made. If redemption is not made until after the required notice of foreclosure of right to redeem has been given, there shall be added to the redemption price the cost in connection with serving the notice, the cost of publication of the notice, if any, and the further sum of 20 percent of the amount paid for the property of the sale to cover the cost of making the necessary examination to determine the person upon whom notice should be served. All of the amounts required to be paid hereunder shall be paid to the purchaser at the tax sale or to his successors. (Code 1989, § 8-76; Ord. No. 263, § 16, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-155. - Effect of redemption.     When property has been redeemed, the effect of the redemption shall be to put the title conveyed by the tax sale back into the defendant in fi. fa, subject to all liens existing at the time of the tax sale. If the redemption has been made by any creditor of the defendant or by any person having any interest in the property, the amount expended by the creditor or person interested shall constitute a first lien on the property and, if the quit-claim deed provided for in section 42-156 is recorded as required by law, shall be repaid prior to any other claims upon the property. (Code 1989, § 8-77; Ord. No. 263, § 17, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-156. - Quit-claim deed by purchaser.     In all cases where property is redeemed, the purchaser at the tax sale shall make a quit-claim deed to the defendant in fi. fa, which deed shall recite the name of the person who has paid the redemption money and the capacity in which, or the claim of right or interest pursuant to which, the redemption money was paid. (Code 1989, § 8-78; Ord. No. 263, § 18, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-157. - Notice of foreclosure of right to redeem; time.     After 12 months from the date of a tax sale, the purchaser at the sale or his heirs, successors or assigns may terminate, foreclose, divest and forever bar the right to redeem the property from the sale by causing a notice of the foreclosure as prescribed by state law to be served as provided by state law. (Code 1989, § 8-79; Ord. No. 263, § 19, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-158. - Sale of property bought by city at tax sale and not redeemed.     Where property purchased by the city at a tax sale by the municipal tax collector has not been redeemed as provided by law, it may be sold by the city in accordance with state law. (Code 1989, § 8-80; Ord. No. 263, § 20, 10-23-1989) 
Sec. 42-159. - Execution of deeds.     It shall be the duty of the municipal tax collector to execute deeds to purchasers at tax sales under executions. (Code 1989, § 8-81; Ord. No. 263, § 21, 10-23-1989) 
Secs. 42-160—42-186. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOTEL-MOTEL TAX[4] Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51. 
Sec. 42-187. - Title.     This article shall be referred to and commonly known as the "Alpharetta Hotel/Motel Tax Ordinance." The authority to levy this tax is granted through O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(2). (Code 1989, § 8-21; Ord. No. 256, § 1, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-188. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Due date means the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed.     Guestroom means a room in any hotel (as defined in this section) which is occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants as living quarters or as residential use.     Hotel means any building or structure kept, used or maintained as or advertised or held out to furnish for value to the public any room, lodging, or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodging or accommodations are regularly furnished for value.     Monthly period means any calendar month of any year.     Occupancy means the use or possession of, or the right to use or possess, any guestroom, or the right to use or possess any of the furnishings, services or accommodations accompanying the use of possession of a guestroom.     Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any guestroom under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement.     Operator/innkeeper means any person operating a hotel (as defined in this section) in the city, including, but not limited to, the hotel owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee, or any other person otherwise operating such hotel.     Person means any natural person, receiver, administrator, executor, conservator, assignee, trust in perpetuity, trust, estate, firm, co-partnership, joint venture, club, company, business trust, domestic or foreign corporation, association, syndicate, society, or any group of individuals acting as a unit, whether mutual, cooperative, fraternal, nonprofit, or otherwise.     Rent or rental means the consideration or value received in money or otherwise for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever.     Return means any return filed or required to be filed as herein provided.     Tax means the tax imposed by this article, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(2). (Code 1989, § 8-22; Ord. No. 256, § 2, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004; Ord. No. 633, § 1, 6-22-2009) 
Sec. 42-189. - Imposition and rate. (a)  This excise tax shall be imposed on any person or legal entity licensed by or required to pay a business or occupation tax to the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground or any other place in which rooms, lodging, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value and shall apply to the furnishing for value of any room, lodging, or accommodation. Every person or entity subject to a tax levied as provided in this article shall be liable for the tax at the applicable rate on the lodging charges actually collected or, if the amount of taxes collected is in excess of the total amount that should have been collected, the total amount actually collected must be remitted. (b)  Any tax levied as provided in this article is also imposed upon every person or entity who is a hotel guest and who receives a room, lodging, or accommodation that is subject to the tax levied under this article. Every such guest subject to the tax levied under this article shall pay the tax to the person or entity providing the room, lodging, or accommodation. The tax shall be of a debt of the person obtaining the room, lodging, or accommodation to the person or entity providing such room, lodging, or accommodation until it is paid, and shall be recoverable by law by the person or entity providing such room, lodging, or accommodation in the same manner as the recovery of other debts. The person or entity collecting the tax from the hotel guest shall remit the tax to the city in concurrence with the provisions of this article. (c)  Commencing on October 1, 2015, there is hereby imposed and there shall be paid to the city an excise tax in the amount of eight percent of the gross rental charge for every occupancy of a guest room in a hotel in the city, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(2). (Code 1989, § 8-23; Ord. No. 256, § 3, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 397, § 1, 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 443, § 1, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004; Ord. No. 709, § 2, 8-17-2015) 
Sec. 42-190. - Exemptions. (a)  The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to charges made for any rooms, lodging, or accommodations provided to any persons who certify that they are staying in such rooms, lodging, or accommodations as a result of the destruction of their homes or residences by fire or other casualty. (b)  The tax authorized by this article shall apply to the fees or charges for any rooms, lodging, or accommodations during the first 30 days of continuous occupancy, and shall not apply to charges imposed for any continuous occupancy thereafter. (c)  The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to charges made for the use of meeting rooms and other such facilities or to any rooms, lodging, or accommodations provided without charge. (d)  The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to the charges for any rooms, lodging, or accommodations furnished for a period of one or more days for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business. Notwithstanding the availability of any other means of identifying the person as a state or local government official or employee, whenever a person pays for any rooms, lodging, or accommodations with a state or local government credit or debit card, such rooms, lodging, or accommodations shall be deemed to have been furnished for use by a state or local government official or employee traveling on official business for purposes of the exemption provided by this section. (Code 1989, § 8-24; Ord. No. 256, § 4, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004; Ord. No. 633, § 2, 6-22-2009) 
Sec. 42-191. - Collection.     The tax levied herein shall be secured by the operator from the occupant when collecting the rent to which it applies. (Code 1989, § 8-25; Ord. No. 256, § 5, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-192. - Registration of operator; form and content; execution; certificate of authority.     No person shall be granted a license as an operator in this city until such person meets all the requirements for operating a hotel within the city and registers with the finance director pursuant to this section. The registration set forth in this section shall require the name under which such person operates a hotel or intends to operate a hotel, the location of the hotel, and such other information which the finance director deems necessary in facilitating the collection of the tax. The registration shall be signed by the operator/owner, if a natural person, and, if the operator shall not be a natural person, then anyone authorized to sign on behalf of the operator. The finance director shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to the registered operator to collect the tax. A separate registration shall be required for each hotel of an operator. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the hotel to which it is applicable. (Code 1989, § 8-26; Ord. No. 256, § 6, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-193. - Returns; due dates of taxes and payments; collection fee allowed operators. (a)  Returns; time of filing; persons required to file; contents. On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period for which the tax is levied, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the finance director showing the gross rent, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the mayor and council or finance director. (b)  Due date of taxes. The taxes required to be collected under this article shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the 20th day of every month following each respective monthly period for which the tax is levied. (c)  Collection fee allowed operators. In reporting and paying the amount of tax due under this article, each operator shall be allowed a deduction of three percent of the amount due, but only if the amount due was not delinquent at the time of payment. (Code 1989, § 8-27; Ord. No. 256, § 7, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-194. - Determination of deficiency; notice of determination; interest on deficiency. (a)  Determination of deficiency. Should the finance director believe that any return filed pursuant to this article does not reflect accurately the amount of tax required to be paid to the city, the finance director may determine the amount which is believed to be the appropriate amount of tax due. (b)  Notice of determination; service of notice. The finance director or his designee shall give written notice of the determination of deficiency. The notice may be served personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested. If notice is given by certified mail, it shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the business license issued to the operator. Service by certified mail will be deemed complete on the date the return receipt is signed by the addressee. Should the addressee fail for any reason to accept delivery, notice shall be deemed given upon the expiration of five days after the notice is mailed by the finance director or his designee. (c)  Collection of deficiency. Within 15 days after the operator receives a notice of determination of deficiency, the operator shall remit to the finance director the amount of deficiency owing, or provide the finance director with a satisfactory explanation in writing which sets forth the reasons such deficiency amount is not owing to the city. (d)  Penalty. The amount of the deficiency shall bear a penalty of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, on the past due amount, from the original due date of the tax. (e)  Interest. The amount of the deficiency shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the original due date of the tax. (f)  Repeated failure to file accurate return. Upon an operator's filing two inaccurate returns within any 24-month period, the city shall have the right to revoke an operator's business license. (Code 1989, § 8-28; Ord. No. 256, § 8, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-195. - Failure to make return; effect. (a)  Failure to make return. If any operator fails to make any return required by this article, the finance director shall notify the operator in writing of such failure. The operator shall have 15 days from the date of the notice to remit the return, along with the tax owing. In addition to the tax owing, taxes shall bear interest at an annual rate equal to the bank prime loan rate as posted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in statistical release H. 15 or any publication that may supersede it, plus three percent, to accrue monthly. Such annual interest rate shall be determined for each calendar year based on the first weekly posting of statistical release H. 15 on or after January 1 of each calendar year. Interest shall begin to accrue from the date the tax is due until the date the tax is paid. Should any operator fail to make a return after such 15-day period, the finance director or his designee shall review the operator's records and make a determination as to the tax owing for the monthly period for which the operator failed to make a return. After making a determination of the tax due, the finance director shall mail written notice of such determination to the operator. The operator shall have five days from the date of the notice to pay all sums owing, together with interest, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the determination is made. In addition, the operator shall pay to the city a penalty of five percent of the total amount of tax owing. (b)  Repeated failure to file return. Upon an operator's failure to make two returns within any 24-month period, the city shall have the right to revoke an operator's business license. (Code 1989, § 8-29; Ord. No. 256, § 9, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) State Law reference— O.C.G.A. § 48-2-40; O.C.G.A. § 48-2-44. 
Sec. 42-196. - Administration of article. (a)  Authority. The finance director shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed by this article. (b)  Records required from operators, etc.; form. Each operator required to make a return and pay any tax under this article shall keep and preserve: (1)  Suitable records of the charges taxable under this article; and (2)  Other books of account which are necessary to determine the amount of tax due. (c)  Examination of records; audits. The finance director or his designee may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator in the city in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or, if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount of tax owing to the city. (d)  Authority to require reports; contents. In the administration of the provisions of this article, the finance director may require the filing of additional reports by any persons or class of persons having custody of information relating to the rental of guestrooms in the city. The reports shall be filed when required by the finance director and shall set forth such information as the finance director may require. (Code 1989, § 8-30; Ord. No. 256, § 10, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-197. - Successors and assigns of operator; liability for tax.     If any hotel or operator liable for any tax, interest, or penalty imposed by this article sells his business or quits the business, a final return with payment shall be made within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. The operator's successor or assigns, if any, shall be liable for any unpaid tax, interest, or penalties accrued under this article and unpaid by any former owner or assignor. (Code 1989, § 8-31; Ord. No. 256, § 11, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-198. - Overpayment of tax; tax credit.     In the event an operator remits to the finance director any sum greater than the amount of tax owing, and such fact is brought to the attention of the finance director, the finance director shall credit the amount of overpayment to the operator's account and such credit shall be applied to the amount owing for a successive monthly period. (Code 1989, § 8-32; Ord. No. 256, § 12, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-199. - Appropriation of sums collected.     All sums collected under this article shall be expended for any purpose authorized by law. (Code 1989, § 8-33; Ord. No. 256, § 14, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 397, § 2, 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Sec. 42-200. - Penalties for violation.     Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished according to the penalties described in section 1-8 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. In addition, the city shall be entitled to bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect any amount of delinquent tax, together with interest, court costs, and reasonable attorney's fees, and to recover any other damages which the city may suffer. The imposition or payment of a fine under this section shall not relieve the operator from the obligation to pay any and all taxes due under this article, including applicable interest and penalties. (Code 1989, § 8-34; Ord. No. 256, § 13, 5-8-1989; Ord. No. 507, 9-23-2002; Ord. No. 538, 2-23-2004) 
Chapter 43 - RESERVED 
Chapter 44 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Powers to grant franchise, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2; regulation of cable television systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-18-1. 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
Sec. 44-1. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Article means this article and all modifications and amendments thereto.     Cable services means the term "cable services" as defined in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 and the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, and as may be further amended from time to time (the "Cable Act"). In the event that the term "cable services" is no longer defined in the Cable Act or the definition in the Cable Act otherwise becomes inapplicable, the term "cable services" shall mean "cable services" as defined in the Cable Act immediately prior to such term no longer being defined in the Cable Act, or such definition otherwise becoming inapplicable.     Cable system means any "cable system" as defined in the Cable Act.     Franchise means an initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued by the city, whether such authorization is designated as a franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement or otherwise, which authorizes the occupation and use of the streets, and, where applicable, other city property, to provide telecommunications services.     Grantee means the legal entity to which is granted the right, authority and responsibility to construct, install, operate and maintain a system of equipment as necessary to furnish, supply and distribute cable services or other telecommunications services to inhabitants within the franchise area.     Telecommunications services means the receipt and/or distribution, through any means, including, without limitation, coaxial cable, optical fiber, or satellite or microwave transmission, of one or more audio, voice or data signals. The term "telecommunications services" includes both cable services and non-cable telecommunications services. (Code 1989, § 17.5-20; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Secs. 44-2—44-20. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sec. 44-21. - Delegation.     Consistent with applicable law, the city council shall have the right to delegate and re-delegate, and to revoke such delegation or re-delegation, from time to time, any of its rights or obligations under this article to any body, organization or official. Any such delegation, re-delegation or revocation, no matter how often made, shall not be deemed an amendment to this article or to require the consent of any applicant for a franchise or franchisee. The city council may also establish and appoint one or more advisory boards, with such duration and such number of members as the city council shall determine, to advise it on such of the matters which are the subject of this article. (Code 1989, § 17.5-30; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Secs. 44-22—44-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TELEPHONE COMPANIES 
Sec. 44-48. - Telephone companies. (a)  Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. The city hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1(b)(8) and (9). (b)  Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights-of-way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. (c)  Authorized designee. The director of finance shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the city under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1 et seq., and shall perform the following duties: (1)  Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within 15 business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. (2)  Report the receipt of a completed application to the council within 60 calendar days of the receipt of such completed application. (3)  Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this section. (4)  Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this section. (5)  Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. (6)  Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights-of-way written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. (Code 1989, § 12-21; Ord. No. 114, § 1, 4-12-1971; Ord. No. 632, § 1, 6-22-2009) State Law reference— Construction of telegraph or telephone lines, O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1. 
Secs. 44-49—44-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GRANTING AUTHORITY AND FRANCHISE PROCEDURE 
Sec. 44-70. - Granting authority. (a)  No person shall provide cable services or operate a cable system without a franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of this article, and no person shall use or occupy city property, including streets, to provide any telecommunications services without a franchise granted in accordance with the provisions of this article. (b)  The city council may grant one or more franchises in accordance with this article, provided that the city council reserves the right to modify any provision of this article by amendment hereof. (c)  The grant of any franchise shall be made by adoption of a separate ordinance by the city council and shall be on such terms and conditions as may be specified in said separate ordinance and/or a franchise agreement between the city and the franchisee. (d)  Any franchise granted shall be non-exclusive. The city specifically reserves the right to: (1)  Grant, at any time, such additional franchises as it deems appropriate; and (2)  Engage, for itself, in the provision of telecommunications services. (e)  The grant of franchises by the city shall be subject to the provisions of applicable law, such as the provisions in the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, governing cable television franchises and renewals thereof. (Code 1989, § 17.5-21; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 44-71. - Franchise applications. (a)  Applications for franchises shall be submitted in such form and be issued on such terms and conditions as the city council may determine, subject to applicable law. (b)  Any application for a franchise shall contain the following information with respect to the proposed franchise unless waived by the city council, and shall contain such other information as the city council shall deem necessary or appropriate: (1)  The applicant's name, address, telephone number, and federal employer identification number or social security number; a copy of the applicant's corporate charter, partnership agreement or other appropriate organizational documentation as is applicable; and any trade names (and registrations) used by the applicant; (2)  A detailed statement of the applicant, including, but not limited to, the following, and to whatever extent required by the city: a.  The names and the residence and business addresses of all officers, directors, members, managing partners and/or managing principals of the applicant as may be applicable; b.  The names, and residence and business addresses of all persons and entities having any share of the ownership of the applicant and the respective ownership share of each person or entity; c.  The name and address of any parent or subsidiary of the applicant, namely, any other business entity owning or controlling the applicant in whole or in part, or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the applicant, and a statement describing the nature of any such parent or subsidiary business entity, including, but not limited to, telecommunications or cable systems owned or controlled by the applicant, its parent, and subsidiary, and the areas served thereby; d.  A detailed and complete financial statement of the applicant, certified by an independent certified public accountant, for the fiscal year immediately preceding the date of the application hereunder, or a letter or other acceptable evidence in writing from a recognized lending institution or funding source, addressed to both the applicant and the city council, setting forth the basis for a study performed by such lending institution or funding source, and a clear statement of its intent as a lending institution or funding source to provide whatever capital shall be required by the applicant to construct and operate the proposed telecommunications or cable system in the city, or a statement from an independent certified public accountant certifying that the applicant has available sufficient free, net, and uncommitted cash resources to construct and operate the proposed cable or telecommunications system in the city; e.  A detailed financial plan (pro forma) describing, for each year of the franchise, the projected number of subscribers, rates, all revenues, operating expenses, capital expenditures, depreciation schedules, income statements, and a sources and uses of funds statement; and f.  A statement identifying, by place and date, any other cable system or telecommunications franchise awarded to the applicant, its parent or subsidiary; the status of said franchise with respect to completion thereof; the total cost of completion of such franchised cable or telecommunication system; and the amount of the applicant's and its parent's or subsidiary's resources committed to the completion thereof; (3)  A detailed description of the proposed plan of operation of the applicant which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: a.  A description of the cable services and any other telecommunications services proposed to be provided; b.  A detailed map indicating all areas proposed to be served, and a proposed time schedule for the installation of all equipment necessary to become operational throughout the entire area to be serviced; c.  A statement or schedule setting forth all proposed classifications or rates and charges to be made against subscribers and all rates and charges as to each of said classifications, including installation charges, charges for cable service, and charges for any other telecommunications service; d.  A detailed, informative, and referenced statement describing the actual equipment and operational standards proposed by the applicant; e.  A copy of the form of any agreement, undertaking, or other instrument proposed to be entered into between the applicant and any subscriber to or for cable services or any other telecommunications services; and f.  A detailed statement setting forth in entirety any and all agreements and undertakings, whether formal or informal, written, oral, or implied, existing or proposed to exist between the applicant and any person, firm, or corporation which materially relate or pertain to or depend upon the application and the granting of the franchise; (4)  A copy of any agreement covering the franchise area between the applicant and any utility providing for the use of any facilities of the utility, including, but not limited to, poles, lines, or conduits; and (5)  Any other details, statements, supplementary information, or references pertinent to the subject matter of such application which shall be required or requested by the council, or by any other provision of law. (Code 1989, § 17.5-22; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 44-72. - Non-refundable application fees for new franchises. (a)  Application fees. No application for a new franchise shall be considered without payment by the applicant of application fees as provided in this section. If a franchise is granted, application fees will not be deemed a credit towards any other fees or sums due by the grantee. If an application is denied, the application fee will not be refunded. (b)  Purpose. The application fees provided by this section will serve to cover the direct and indirect costs incurred by the city in processing and analyzing the application and related documentation, evaluating the applicant and any related entities or matters, and granting a franchise, and shall include, but not be limited to, administrative, engineering, publication, legal, and consultant's fees and expenses. (c)  Payment. The applicant will be expected to pay the reasonable costs of the city in evaluating the application. Notwithstanding any other requirement of this article, each applicant must furnish with his proposal a non-refundable application fee in the amount of $10,000.00, by certified check or cashier's check made payable to the city. (Code 1989, § 17.5-23; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 44-73. - Responsibilities of applicants.     It shall be the responsibility of each applicant for a franchise to comply with all applicable laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules, regulations and other directives of the city and any federal, state or local governmental authority having jurisdiction. (Code 1989, § 17.5-24; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 44-74. - Public availability of applications.     To the extent determined by the city council, applications for franchises, including any additions, modifications or amendments thereto, shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours. (Code 1989, § 17.5-25; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 44-75. - Evaluation criteria.     In making any determination hereunder as to any application for a franchise, the city council may consider such factors as it deems appropriate and in the public interest, including, without limitation: (1)  The adequacy of the proposed compensation to be paid to the city, including the value of any facilities and telecommunications services offered by the applicant to the city; (2)  The legal, financial, technical and other appropriate qualifications of the applicant, and where applicable, related entities; (3)  The ability of the applicant to maintain the property of the city in good condition throughout the term of the franchise; (4)  The value and efficiency to the city and its residents of the cable services and other telecommunications services to be provided, including the type of cable services and telecommunications services to be provided, as well as alternatives to those cable and telecommunications services and services that may be precluded by the grant of the franchise; (5)  The willingness and ability of the applicant to meet construction and physical requirements and to abide by all purpose and policy conditions, limitations and requirements with respect to the franchise; and (6)  Any other public interest factors or considerations deemed pertinent by the city for safeguarding the interests of the city and the public. (Code 1989, § 17.5-26; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 44-76. - Procedure for consideration of and action on applications. (a)  The city may make such investigations and take or authorize the taking of such other steps as the city council deems necessary or appropriate to consider and act on applications for franchises and determine whether a franchise should be granted to an applicant, and may require the applicant to furnish additional information and data for this purpose. In considering applications, the city council may seek advice from other city officials or bodies, from such other advisory bodies as it may establish or determine appropriate, or from the public, and may request the preparation of one or more reports to be submitted to the city council, which may include recommendations with respect to such applications. (b)  If the city council, after considering such information as it determines to be appropriate, elects to further consider one or more applications, the city council may set one or more public hearings for consideration of the application, fixing and setting forth a day, hour and place certain when and where any persons having any interest therein or objections thereto may file written comments and appear before the city council and be heard, and providing notice of such public hearing in accordance with applicable law. (c)  The city council may authorize negotiations between city officials and applicants to determine whether the city and such applicants are able to reach agreement on the terms of the proposed franchise. (d)  Upon completion of the steps deemed appropriate by the city council, the city council may grant the franchise, and may specify the conditions under which the franchise is granted. Alternatively, the city may reject any and all applications from whatever source and whenever received, except that the city as franchising authority may not grant an exclusive franchise. The city also reserves the right to waive any or all requirements when it determines that the best interests of the city may be served thereby and may, if it so desires, request new or additional proposals. (Code 1989, § 17.5-27; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Sec. 44-77. - Terms and conditions of franchise.     The terms and conditions applicable to any franchise granted pursuant to this article shall be set forth in the separate ordinance granting the franchise or in a separate written agreement. Such separate ordinance or written agreement, among other things, shall address the following subjects, unless otherwise waived by the city: (1)  The term of the franchise; (2)  The franchise area and the cable services and other telecommunications services and purposes of such other telecommunications services, if any, which are the subject of a franchise; (3)  The compensation to be paid to the city, which may include the payment of fees or the provision of facilities or services, or both; (4)  The circumstances upon which the franchise may be terminated or canceled; (5)  The mechanisms, such as performance bonds, security funds or letters of credit, to be put in place to insure the performance of the franchisee's obligations under the franchise; (6)  The city's right to inspect the facilities and records of the franchisee; (7)  Insurance and indemnification requirements applicable to the franchisee; (8)  The obligation of the franchisee to maintain complete and accurate books of account and records, and the city's inspection rights with respect thereto; (9)  Provisions to ensure quality workmanship and construction methods; (10)  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will comply with all applicable city, state and federal laws, regulations, rules and policies, including, without limitation, those related to employment, purchasing and investigations; (11)  Provisions to ensure adequate oversight and regulation of the franchisee by the city; (12)  Provisions to restrict the assignment or other transfer of the franchise without the prior written consent of the city; (13)  Remedies available to the city to protect the city's interest in the event of the franchisee's failure to comply with terms and conditions of the franchise; (14)  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will obtain all necessary licenses and permits from, and comply with, all laws, regulations, rules and policies of any governmental body having jurisdiction over the franchisee, including the Federal Communications Commission; (15)  Provisions to ensure that the franchisee will protect the property of the city and the delivery of public services from damage or interruption of operations resulting from the construction, operation, maintenance, repair or removal of improvements related to the franchise; (16)  Provisions designed to minimize the extent to which the public use of the streets of the city are disrupted in connection with the construction of improvements relating to the franchise; and (17)  Such other provisions as the city determines are necessary or appropriate in furtherance of the public interest. (Code 1989, § 17.5-28; Ord. No. 394, § 1, 8-4-1997) 
Chapter 45 - RESERVED 
Chapter 46 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); powers of cities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; jurisdiction of municipal court of violation of driver's license statute, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-124; operating motor vehicle without license, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-22; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372. 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
Sec. 46-1. - Adoption of state law by reference. (a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, entitled "definitions," and O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-395, known as the "Uniform Rules of the Road," are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this municipality with like effect as if recited herein. (b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. (c)  The provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-160 regarding school buses are hereby adopted and made applicable to and shall be effective upon the private roads in the city to the same extent and with the same effect as the provisions of such sections apply to the public streets in the city. Further, the city police department is hereby empowered and authorized to enforce all provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-160 through 40-6-164 upon all private roads in the city. (Code 1989, § 18-1; Ord. No. 229, § 1, 8-10-1987; Ord. No. 254, § 2, 3-13-1989; Ord. No. 411, § 1, 8-24-1998) 
Sec. 46-2. - Speed limits—Schedule. (a)  The speed limit schedule shall be determined by the city council from time to time, and is on file at the city court. (b)  School zone hours effective: (1)  School days only (a.m.): from 45 minutes prior to commencement time to 15 minutes after commencement time. (2)  School days only (p.m.): from 15 minutes prior to dismissal time to 45 minutes after dismissal time. (c)  Signs are to be erected by the city. (Code 1989, § 18-2; Ord. No. 253-A, § 2, 2-13-1989; Ord. No. 262, 9-25-1989; Ord. No. 309, 9-28-1992; Ord. No. 348, § 1, 6-20-1994; Ord. No. 375, 4-1-1996; Ord. No. 385, 1-27-1997; Ord. No. 423, § 1, 6-21-1998; Ord. No. 449, §§ 1—3, 8-21-2000; Ord. No. 487, §§ 1—29, 2-4-2002; Ord. No. 543, 4-19-2004; Ord. No. 599, 8-21-2006; Ord. No. 617, 2-18-2008; Ord. No. 628, §§ 1—5, 2-2-2009; Ord. No. 645, §§ 1—34, 9-20-2010; Ord. No. 669, §§ 1—31, 11-5-2012) State Law reference— Maximum limits generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-181; authority to alter, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. 
Sec. 46-3. - Same—Erection of signs.     Signs on the state highway system shall be erected by the state department of transportation. All others shall be erected by the city. (Code 1989, § 18-3; Ord. No. 253-A, § 2, 2-13-1989) 
Sec. 46-4. - Truck routes—Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Truck means a motor vehicle having a gross vehicular weight rating (G.V.W.R.) in excess of 36,000 pounds or having an overall length in excess of 30 feet, except vehicles designed to carry passengers.     Truck route means any street or portion thereof, within the city, over which trucks are not prohibited to operate by the provisions of section 46-4.5. (Code 1989, § 18-4; Ord. No. 140, § 1, 11-18-1974; Ord. No. 754, § 1, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 46-4.5. - Same—Designated. (a)  Except as specifically set out herein, trucks are prohibited from using any street within the city except those designated below: (1)  SR 9 (North Main Street - South Main Street). (2)  SR 120. (3)  Haynes Bridge Road (SR 120 to city limits). (4)  Hembree Road (Westside Parkway to Roswell city limits continuing on Roswell truck route). (5)  Mansell Road. (6)  Maxwell Road (SR 9 to Hembree Road). (7)  McGinnis Ferry Road. (8)  North Point Parkway. (9)  Union Hill Road. (10)  Westside Parkway. (11)  Windward Concourse. (12)  Windward Parkway (SR 9 to Union Hill Road). (b)  Exceptions to the above schedule are as follows: (1)  When the terminal, parking lot, repair garage, headquarters, place of pickup or delivery of the restricted motor vehicle is not on a designated truck route, ingress to and egress from such places shall be made by the most direct route available between the terminal, parking lot, repair garage, headquarters, place of pickup or delivery and the nearest designated truck route. (Ord. No. 754, § 1, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 46-5. - Same—Enforcement. (a)  The city clerk shall keep and maintain an accurate map setting out truck routes and streets upon which truck traffic is permitted; the maps shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available to the public. (b)  The public works director shall cause those streets upon which truck traffic is prohibited to be clearly sign-posted to give notice that section 46-4.5 is in effect. (Code 1989, § 18-6; Ord. No. 140, § 3, 11-18-1972; Ord. No. 754, § 1, 4-9-2018) 
Sec. 46-6. - Hazardous driving.     It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle of any kind within the limits of this city in a hazardous manner, regardless of speed. The term "hazardous driving" is defined to be driving any vehicle of any kind on any street in the city in such a manner as to endanger the life or limb of any person, or any damage to personal property that might result therefrom, taking into consideration the conditions and surroundings of such time and place that a careful and prudent person would observe. (Code 1989, § 18-7; Ord. No. 87, § 8.2, 9-3-1962) 
Sec. 46-7. - Funeral processions.     Vehicles of a funeral procession shall have the right-of-way over all vehicles, except authorized emergency vehicles, provided such vehicles shall identify themselves by burning regular headlights and shall keep in close formation. When the lead vehicle in a funeral procession has entered an intersection on a green light, all other cars in the procession may proceed through the intersection, even though such signal may change to red. (Code 1989, § 18-8; Ord. No. 87, § 8.10, 9-3-1962) State Law reference— Funeral processions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-76. 
Secs. 46-8—46-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING 
Sec. 46-33. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Parking enforcement officer means non-sworn personnel designated by the director of public safety or his designee, for the purpose of enforcing parking regulations, including issuance of citations and/or towing of vehicles parked in restricted areas. (Code 1989, § 18-20; Ord. No. 216, § 2, 11-11-1985; Ord. No. 717, § 1, 12-14-2015) 
Sec. 46-34. - Designation of parking areas; marking. (a)  The chief of police is authorized to designate specific parking areas or zones within the city in which the parking of vehicles is regulated or prohibited. The chief of police shall make such determinations upon the basis of any engineering and traffic investigations indicating that the adoption of such regulations and prohibitions will aid in the reasonable regulation and control of the parking of vehicles and the reasonable movement of traffic. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the chief of police is authorized to designate areas or zones in which: (1)  Parking is prohibited at all times or at designated times; (2)  Parking is permitted for specified types of vehicles only; or (3)  Parking may not exceed a specified consecutive period of time. (b)  Each parking area or zone shall be marked or indicated by adequate signs setting forth the applicable restriction in a sufficiently legible manner. (Code 1989, § 18-21; Ord. No. 216, § 1, 11-11-1985) 
Sec. 46-35. - Compliance with no-parking or restricted parking markings or signs.     It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on any street in the city where such street or place of such parking has painted thereat a yellow or no parking line, or has erected thereat signs providing for parking, or to fail to comply with such marking or sign which limits parking thereat. (Code 1989, § 18-22; Ord. No. 126, 4-9-1973)
