Sec. 46-36. - Enforcement; fine, impoundment of vehicle.     Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine to be determined by the city council from time to time. All parking enforcement officers and police officers shall enforce the provisions of this article, and shall be empowered to issue written citations requiring the accused to appear to answer the charge. In addition, where any vehicle has been left unattended in a restricted zone for 24 hours or more, the parking enforcement officer or police officer is authorized to cause the vehicle to be towed away to the nearest garage or other place of safety, at the expense of the owner of the vehicle. (Code 1989, § 18-23; Ord. No. 216, § 3, 11-11-1985; Ord. No. 717, § 2, 12-14-2015) State Law reference— Impoundment of vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-206. 
Secs. 46-37—46-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARADES, MOTORCADES AND SPECIAL EVENTS[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Operation of motor vehicles and motorcycles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7. 
Sec. 46-61. - Definitions. (a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Motorcade means an organized procession containing 25 or more vehicles, except funeral processions, upon any public street, sidewalk or alley.     Parade means any march or procession consisting of people, animals or vehicles or a combination thereof, except funeral processions, upon any public street, sidewalk or alley, which does not comply with normal and usual traffic regulations or controls.     Special event means any activity which occurs upon private or public property that will affect the ordinary use of public streets, rights-of-way or sidewalks. This includes, but is not limited to, fairs, festivals, foot runs and bicycle runs. (b)  Private social gatherings, neighborhood block parties and neighborhood parades conducted primarily on subdivision streets within the neighborhood and which will make only limited use of other city streets are not included in these definitions. However, no such event shall be held unless and until an exemption letter for such event has been obtained from the director of recreation and parks or his designee. No fee shall be charged for an exemption letter. (Code 1989, § 18-36; Ord. No. 370, § 1, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-62. - Permit required.     No person or organization shall conduct a parade, motorcade or special event within the city, or knowingly participate in any such parade, motorcade or special event, unless and until a permit to conduct such parade, motorcade or special event has been obtained from the city traffic engineer, or, as hereinafter provided, from the city council. (Code 1989, § 18-37; Ord. No. 370, § 2, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-63. - Parade, motorcade or special event for commercial purpose prohibited.     No permit shall be issued authorizing the conduct of a parade, motorcade or special event which the city traffic engineer finds is to be held for the primary purpose of advertising any products, goods, wares, merchandise or events and is designed to be held primarily for private profit. Otherwise, permits shall be issued on a non-discriminatory basis. (Code 1989, § 18-38; Ord. No. 370, § 3, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-64. - Interference with parade, motorcade or special event.     No person shall knowingly join or participate in any parade, motorcade or special event conducted under permit from the city traffic engineer in violation of any of the terms of the permit, nor knowingly join in or participate in any permitted parade, motorcade or special event without the consent or over the objection of the permittee, nor in any manner interfere with its progress or orderly conduct. (Code 1989, § 18-39; Ord. No. 370, § 4, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-65. - Permit application and fee.     An application for a permit shall be submitted to the city traffic engineer with a non-refundable application fee that shall be established by the city council, from time to time, and made available for public examination in the office of the clerk of courts no later than 30 days prior to the proposed event. The city traffic engineer may, in his discretion, consider an application for a permit which is filed less than 30 days prior to the date of the event. The permit application shall be made in writing on a form approved by the city traffic engineer. The application shall contain the following information: (1)  The name, address and telephone number of the sponsoring organization or individual, including the name, address and telephone number of an individual who shall be designated as a contact person and agent for service of process; (2)  The proposed date, location, hours of operation and schedule of proposed events, including the location of the assembly area, the location of the disbanding area, and any route to be traveled; (3)  An estimate of the number of participants, and the number of individuals that will be utilized to monitor and control the event; (4)  A description of any sound amplification equipment proposed to be used; and (5)  Such other information as the city traffic engineer deems reasonably necessary to determine whether a permit may be issued. (Code 1989, § 18-40; Ord. No. 370, § 5, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-66. - Standards for issuance or denial of permit.     The city traffic engineer may deny a permit upon reasonably determining that: (1)  The event will disrupt traffic within the city beyond practical solution; (2)  The event will unreasonably interfere with access to fire stations and fire hydrants; (3)  The location of the event will cause extreme hardship to adjacent businesses or residents; (4)  The event will require the diversion of so many public employees that allowing the event would unreasonably deny service to the remainder of the city; (5)  The event will interfere with another event for which a permit has been issued; and (6)  The applicant refuses to sign the permit indicating his willingness to abide by or comply with the provisions of this article and the conditions set forth in the permit. (Code 1989, § 18-41; Ord. No. 370, § 6, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-67. - Departmental cost analysis; permit fee.     The city traffic engineer shall send copies of a permit application to all affected city departments. Each departmental activity required for the event shall be itemized, showing hourly rate and total cost. Costs shall only reflect those activities related to the management of streets. The total street management costs to the city shall be the sum of each department's costs, and shall be the amount of the permit fee. The permit fee shall not be applicable to any event sponsored or co-sponsored by the city, or to any event designated from time to time by resolution of the city council as a traditional or historic annual event. An example of a traditional or historic annual event is the Old Soldier's Day Parade. The city traffic engineer may develop a permit fee schedule based upon the size of the event, provided that the fee schedule is reasonably related to the actual street management costs of the city. The city traffic engineer shall also develop a clean-up cost deposit schedule based upon the size of the event. (Code 1989, § 18-42; Ord. No. 370, § 7, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-68. - Issuance of permit.     Upon payment of the permit fee and clean-up cost deposit, and execution of the permit by the applicant indicating the applicant's agreement to abide by this article and the conditions set forth in the permit, the city traffic engineer shall issue the permit. The conditions of the permit shall include specifications as to the date, location, size and time limits for the event, limitations on amplification equipment, the maximum number and type of vehicles, if any, the maximum number of participants, and the minimum number of persons required to monitor the event. In addition, each permit shall contain a condition that the permittee shall hold the city harmless and indemnify the city, its officials and employees, from any and all claims or lawsuits for personal injury or property damage arising from or in any way connected to the event, except for any claims arising solely out of the negligent acts of the city, its officials or employees. In addition, the city traffic engineer may, in his discretion, require proof that the permittee has insurance, with limits of coverage, as determined by the city traffic engineer, adequate for the risks associated with the event and to support the permittee's indemnity obligations to the city. (Code 1989, § 18-43; Ord. No. 370, § 8, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-69. - Limitation of liability.     This article shall not constitute a waiver of sovereign immunity, create rights in any third party, or impose upon the city or its officials or employees any liability or responsibility for any injury or damage to any person or property arising out of the event for which a permit has been issued. The city and its officials and employees shall not be deemed to have assumed any liability or responsibility by reason of inspections performed, the issuance of any permit, or the approval of the use of any city right-of-way. (Code 1989, § 18-44; Ord. No. 370, § 9, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-70. - Sanitation and clean up.     A permit may be issued only after adequate waste disposal facilities have been identified and obtained by the permittee. The permittee will clean the rights-of-way of rubbish and debris, returning the rights-of-way to their previous condition, within 24 hours of the conclusion of the event. If the permittee completes the clean-up in a timely manner, the clean-up cost deposit shall be refunded. If the permittee fails to clean up such refuse, the city may perform the clean-up, and the clean-up cost deposit shall be forfeited. (Code 1989, § 18-45; Ord. No. 370, § 10, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-71. - Revocation of permits. (a)  All permits issued pursuant to this article are temporary and do not vest any permanent rights. Any permit may be summarily revoked by the city traffic engineer upon a determination by the city traffic engineer that: (1)  The permit application contained incomplete or false information; (2)  The applicant is not complying with all terms and conditions of the permit or this article; or (3)  The occurrence of an emergency which threatens the safety of the public or property. (b)  Notice of the revocation shall be delivered in writing to the registered agent of the permittee designated in the permit application. Delivery may be by personal service or certified mail, return receipt requested, and notice shall be deemed given when personally served or when deposited in the mail, as the case may be. (Code 1989, § 18-46; Ord. No. 370, § 11, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-72. - Appeals procedure.     Any applicant whose permit application has been denied or revoked may appeal from the determination of the city traffic engineer within five days thereafter to the city council, by filing a written notice of appeal for a hearing by the city council at its next meeting. Upon such appeal, the city council may reverse, affirm or modify in any regard the determination of the city traffic engineer. (Code 1989, § 18-47; Ord. No. 370, § 12, 2-19-1996) 
Sec. 46-73. - Penalty.     In addition to any other remedy provided under this article or other applicable law, any person who violates any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine according to the penalties described in section 1-8. Each day that an offense occurs or continues under this article shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. (Code 1989, § 18-49; Ord. No. 370, § 14, 2-19-1996) 
Secs. 46-74—46-91. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNAL MONITORING DEVICES[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Traffic control signal monitoring devices generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20; permit to operate traffic control signal monitoring system, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-21. 
Sec. 46-92. - Authorization of traffic control signal monitoring devices.     Subject to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-14-21, the chief of police and the city council authorize the use of traffic control signal monitoring devices for purposes of automated traffic enforcement. Use of said devices shall be governed by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-20 through 40-14-24, and any other applicable provisions of law. (Code 1989, § 18-62; Ord. No. 568, § 1, 6-6-2005) 
Sec. 46-93. - Identification of intersections for use of traffic control signal monitoring devices.     The city department of public works shall be responsible for the identification and selection of intersections where traffic control signal monitoring devices will be utilized and for compliance with O.C.G.A. §§ 40-14-22 and 40-14-23. (Code 1989, § 18-63; Ord. No. 568, § 1, 6-6-2005) 
Sec. 46-94. - Enforcement.     The city police department shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this article as required by O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20. (Code 1989, § 18-64; Ord. No. 568, § 1, 6-6-2005) 
Sec. 46-95. - Civil penalty.     The driver of a motor vehicle cited pursuant to this article shall be liable for a civil monetary penalty according to the penalties described in section 1-8. Citations shall be issued by the city police department in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(f)(3)(B). (Code 1989, § 18-65; Ord. No. 568, § 1, 6-6-2005) 
Sec. 46-96. - Contesting the civil penalty. (a)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(d), liability shall be determined based upon preponderance of the evidence. Prima facie evidence that the vehicle described in the citation issued pursuant to this article was operated in violation of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(a), together with proof that the defendant was at the time of such violation the registered owner of the vehicle, shall permit the trier of fact in his discretion to infer that such owner of the vehicle was the driver of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. Such an inference may be rebutted if the owner of the vehicle: (1)  Testifies under oath in open court that he was not the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation; (2)  Presents to the court prior to the return date established on the citation a certified copy of a police report showing that the vehicle had been reported to the police as stolen prior to the time of the alleged violation; or (3)  Submits to the court prior to the return date established on the citation a sworn notarized statement identifying the name of the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. (b)  The provisions of this article shall not limit law enforcement agencies to the use of traffic control signal monitoring devices in enforcing O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(a); and, when there is evidence obtained from another source or sources which constitutes a prima facie case of a violation of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(a), such violation may be prosecuted as otherwise provided by law in lieu of, but not limited to, enforcement under this article. (Code 1989, § 18-66; Ord. No. 568, § 1, 6-6-2005) 
Sec. 46-97. - Warning period.     In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20(f)(3)(B), only warning notices and not citations for violations shall be sent during the 30-day period following the installation of any traffic control signal monitoring device. (Code 1989, § 18-67; Ord. No. 568, § 1, 6-6-2005) 
Secs. 46-98—46-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - READY-MIX CONCRETE TRUCKS 
Sec. 46-125. - Restrictions on ready-mix concrete trucks. (a)  It shall be unlawful to operate any ready-mix concrete truck on the public roads of the city in such a manner so as to result in the spillage or leakage of concrete or similar debris onto any city road or walk. In the event of any such spill, it shall be the duty of the owner and operator of the truck to report the spill to the city department of public works within 24 hours of the spill. In addition, the owner shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the city in removing the concrete and/or repairing the roadway. In the event that the owner fails to reimburse the city for such costs within 30 days after written notice, the city may pursue any and all civil remedies available to the city at law or in equity to recover its costs, including reasonable attorney's fees. Criminal prosecution for any violation of this article shall not relieve any owner from the obligation to reimburse the city for such costs; nor shall payment of such costs bar criminal prosecution for any violation of this article. (b)  In addition to those prohibitions listed above, it shall be unlawful to operate any ready-mix concrete truck on the public roads within the city unless such truck is equipped with a chute enclosure, or some other mechanism which precludes the leakage of concrete and other debris from leaking or escaping from the truck while traveling through or within the city. For purposes of this article, the term "truck" is defined to mean any vehicle with two or more axles used primarily for the purpose of transporting materials and products. (c)  The chute enclosure must meet the following requirements: (1)  The device must be 100 percent effective in keeping debris from coming out of the chute when the device is engaged; (2)  The device must be rigid, open and close, and lock and unlock automatically when the flop chute is lowered or raised; (3)  The device shall have no parts which may become clogged with concrete; (4)  The device must close the chute at the end and seal it completely. No debris shall be able to escape and fall from the chute while the truck is traveling; (5)  The device shall be coated with a reflective paint, tape or logo so that it is clearly visible at night; and (6)  The device shall be permanently attached to the chute of each truck. (d)  Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be fined according to the penalties described in section 1-8; and each violation thereof shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such; and each day that a violation continues shall be punishable as a separate offense. (Code 1989, § 10-61; Ord. No. 417, § 1, 3-15-1999) 
Chapter 47 - RESERVED 
Chapter 48 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
Secs. 48-1—48-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Taxicabs, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-25; regulatory fees, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9. 
Sec. 48-19. - Definitions.     The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:     Taxicab means a motor vehicle used in the business of transporting passengers for compensation in the city and not operated on a fixed route. The term "taxicab" shall not include limousines regulated by the state public service commission. (Code 1989, § 13-146; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-20. - Permits required.     No permit is required if the operation of the taxicab in the city is limited solely to passing through the city without picking up a passenger or dropping off a passenger whose trip originated outside the city. (Code 1989, § 13-147; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 523, § 1, 3-3-2003) 
Sec. 48-21. - Classes of permits.     There shall be three classes of permits required under this article: (1)  Company permit. This permit applies to persons, firms, partnerships, corporations or other entities engaged in the business of operating a taxicab in the city, and which are subject to an occupation tax under chapter 42. (2)  Resident operator's permit. This permit applies to any person operating a taxicab on the streets of the city and who is operating under the auspices of a company permit. (3)  Nonresident operator's permit. This permit applies to any person operating a taxicab on the streets of the city and who is not operating under the auspices of a company subject to an occupation tax in the city. (Code 1989, § 13-148; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-22. - Company permit.     In order to secure a company permit, an applicant must provide information showing its qualifications on a form provided by the city, and must submit to a background investigation and fingerprinting. An applicant must: (1)  Be at least 21 years of age; (2)  Be a citizen of the United States or an alien admitted for permanent residence, or a person who has otherwise been granted employment authorized by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service; (3)  Hold an occupation tax certificate issued by the city; (4)  Maintain an office within the city staffed at all times during hours of operation as outlined in this article by company employees, including a dispatcher, from which all dispatching of vehicles will be performed; (5)  Provide proof of insurance as required in this article. (Code 1989, § 13-149; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-23. - Convictions disqualifying applicant for a company permit.     No permit shall be issued if the applicant has been convicted of any of the following offenses: (1)  Manslaughter, or negligent homicide, resulting from the operation of a motor vehicle. (2)  Driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs, in the last five years. (3)  Any felony in the commission of which a motor vehicle is used. (4)  Failure to stop and render aid or leaving the scene of an accident, as required under the laws of the state. (5)  Perjury or false swearing in making any statements under oath in connection with this application for permit. (6)  Perjury or the making of a false affidavit or statement under oath relating to the ownership or operation of motor vehicles. (7)  Convictions or forfeiture of bail on three charges of a violation of the state motor vehicle laws within a 12-month period. (8)  The violation of any law involving moral turpitude. (9)  Repeated violation of the city ordinances, county laws, or state laws which affect the safety of human life or limb on the streets of the city. (Code 1989, § 13-150; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 523, § 2, 3-3-2003) 
Sec. 48-24. - Place of operation.     No person to whom an occupation tax certificate to operate or engage in a taxicab business has been granted by lawful authority shall operate or carry on the business from any place in the city except the established place of business referred to and described in the application for an occupation tax certificate to operate or engage in the taxicab business. (Code 1989, § 13-151; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-25. - Hours of operation.     The standard hours of operations for any holder of a company permit to operate or engage in a taxicab business within the city shall be Monday through Sunday, 24 hours per day. (Code 1989, § 13-152; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-26. - Insurance required. (a)  No owner of a taxicab shall operate or authorize any other person to operate a taxicab in the city unless it is covered by a liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this state, which provides the following minimum coverage: (1)  $25,000.00 for injury to or death of one person in one accident; (2)  $50,000.00 for injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident; and (3)  $25,000.00 for injury or destruction of property of others in any one accident. (b)  Each taxicab operated within the city limits shall be required to carry and maintain in effect this minimum insurance coverage and provide current certificates of insurance evidencing such coverage, the name of the insurance company supplying the coverage and the policy number. The insurance must provide specific coverage for a vehicle used in the business of transporting passengers. (c)  If the term of said insurance coverage is less than a period of 12 months, on the first Monday of each month, the holder of the company permit shall provide to the chief of police or his designee either a current insurance identification card for each vehicle intended to be operated in the coming month or a verified statement from a licensed insurance agent or licensed insurance company within this state setting forth the identity of the vehicles for which coverage has been procured, by vehicle identification number, make and model, the amount of coverage afforded to each such vehicle and the term for which such coverage has been prepared by the taxicab company or taxicab driver. (d)  If the term of such insurance coverage is at least a period of 12 months, proof of such insurance coverage, together with a receipted premium from the insurer, or its duly authorized agent, showing payment of the premium on the policy for and during the period covered by the life of the occupational tax certificate, shall be provided to the city before a permit shall be issued. The insurance policy must provide and stipulate therein that the insurer will give notice to the city a minimum of 30 days before its termination or cancellation, for any reason, of the policy on the person insured. (e)  Failure to maintain such coverage shall constitute cause for revocation of a city permit. (f)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to waive applicable state or federal laws, if any, which require a higher amount of minimum coverage. (Code 1989, § 13-153; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 523, § 3, 3-3-2003) 
Sec. 48-27. - Drivers' qualifications.     Before operating a taxicab within the city, a driver shall: (1)  Possess a Georgia class C driver's license, with a for-hire endorsement or a private background check certification, through the taxicab service or ride share network service that employs them; (2)  Be competent to operate a motor vehicle; (3)  Be familiar with the traffic laws and ordinances of the city; (4)  Not have been convicted of a felony unless ten years have elapsed since the date of completion of the felony sentence; (5)  Not have been convicted of a crime of moral turpitude within past ten years; (6)  Not have been classified as an habitual offender by the department of public safety for the previous five years; (7)  Not have had a driver's license revoked by the department of public safety for violations for the previous five years; (8)  Provide authorization and any information necessary to enable the director of public safety or his designee to investigate the driver's background, criminal history, and traffic record; (9)  Be of good character as determined by the aforesaid investigation; and (10)  Possess an operator's permit issued by the city. (Code 1989, § 13-154; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 523, § 4, 3-3-2003) 
Sec. 48-28. - Taxicab equipment.     All taxicabs operating in the city shall: (1)  Be equipped with a taximeter maintained in good working order at all times. Such taximeter shall be permanently affixed in front of the passenger's seat and be visible to them at all times. After sundown, the face of the taximeter shall be illuminated. It shall be operated mechanically by a mechanism of standard design and construction, driven either from the transmission or from one of the front wheels by a flexible and permanently attached driving mechanism. It shall be sealed at all points and connections that, if manipulated, would affect its correct reading and recording. (2)  Be affixed with a vehicle permit sticker issued by the director of public safety or his designee. Such stickers must at all times be displayed in the upper right corner of the rear window. Each vehicle will be assigned a numbered sticker, and that sticker shall not be used on any other vehicle. (3)  Such marking shall be affixed only by means of permanent vinyl lettering or paint, and shall be a minimum of four inches in height. The four-inch lettering requirement can be met if the logo is a minimum of four inches in height and the lettering within the logo is a minimum of two inches in height. (4)  Be marked with rates on the side of the vehicle so as to be plainly visible to persons seeking to use the taxicab. (5)  Maintain signage in the passenger compartment stating, in clearly legible lettering of a minimum of one inch in height, "The public is invited to contact the city department of public safety by calling (678)297-6306 to report any instance of a taxicab being operated while not in a clean and safe operating condition." (6)  Be equipped with a roof light permanently mounted on the roof of the vehicle and maintained in good working order at all times. (7)  Be maintained in good, safe and serviceable mechanical condition as verified in a statement signed by a technician at a location properly licensed to do business within the city, and be in compliance with all county and state licensing and emission standards. (8)  Be maintained in a clean condition, free from foreign matter and offensive odors. (9)  Transport as passengers only the number of persons specified by the vehicle manufacturer. (10)  The minimum weight of a taxicab shall be 2,000 pounds, as determined by the manufacturer's specifications. (11)  No vehicle operated as a taxicab shall be more than eight years old. (12)  No taxicab shall have less than three doors for loading passengers, and each taxicab must be a station wagon, a sedan, a minivan or a sports utility vehicle. All such vehicles shall meet the emission standards as set by federal guidelines for their particular class. (Code 1989, § 13-155; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 523, § 5, 3-3-2003) 
Sec. 48-29. - Log books. (a)  Daily trip sheets shall be maintained for all taxicabs operated within the city. The driver shall retain the trip sheets in the vehicle for a period of 72 hours from the time of the recorded trip, after which they will be maintained in the office of the company permit holder for a period of no less than 120 days. All trip sheets shall be subject to the inspection of the police chief or his designee. (b)  As used in this subsection, the term "trip sheet" means a daily log of all passengers, the time, place of entry and the destination of each passenger, the amount charged and an itemization of any personal property left in the vehicle for hire. (Code 1989, § 13-156; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-30. - Transferability.     Any vehicle permit issued in accordance with this article shall not be transferable. (Code 1989, § 13-157; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-31. - Denial, suspension and revocation of permit. (a)  An application for a permit or a permit issued under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked for due cause as defined in subsection (c) of this section. (b)  The municipal court shall furnish a permit holder a notice setting forth the time, place, and purpose of a hearing at which it intends to consider the revocation or suspension of a permit. After a hearing, if the municipal court determines due cause exists, it may suspend, revoke or place on probation for a maximum of 12 months, with or without conditions, the permit. (c)  A permit may be denied, suspended or revoked for any of the following reasons: (1)  Where the applicant furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information or omits information requested in the application for a permit. (2)  For failure to pay all fees, taxes, penalties or other charges imposed by the provisions of this article, and of this Code. (3)  For failure to maintain all of the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of a permit. (4)  For violation of any part of this article by the permit holder, his agents, partners, officers, employees or contractors. (5)  Allowing the required insurance coverage to lapse shall result in the automatic suspension of the permit. (6)  For unauthorized transfer or other misuse of the permit. (d)  An operator's permit may be suspended or revoked for having three or more moving violations in any 12-month period. (e)  Permit holders under this article are responsible for violations of this article by their vehicle operators whether such operators are direct employees or independent contractors. (f)  Permits issued under this article are not transferable. (Code 1989, § 13-158; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 523, § 6, 3-3-2003) 
Sec. 48-32. - Regulatory fee required.     A regulatory fee of $300.00 shall be required annually for a company permit and the resident operator's permits for drivers operating under the auspices of a company permit. A regulatory fee of $50.00 shall be required annually for a nonresident operator's permit. (Code 1989, § 13-159; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 523, § 7, 3-3-2003) 
Sec. 48-33. - Notification of new drivers.     It shall be the duty of a company permit holder to notify the director of public safety whenever a new driver is hired or terminated from employment. Failure to so notify can result in revocation of the permit. (Code 1989, § 13-160; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-34. - Violations. (a)  Repeated violations of traffic laws or ordinances, or of any ordinance provision regulating the conduct of taxicab drivers, shall be cause for revocation of said permit to operate in the city. (b)  It is a violation and grounds for suspension or revocation of an operator permit for any operator to: (1)  Commit more than three traffic infractions within any 12-month period; (2)  Be found guilty of a felony; (3)  Be guilty of reckless driving or driving or being in physical control of a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs; (4)  Fail to deliver to the city police department within 24 hours any property of value left in a vehicle; (5)  Allow a person to alight from the vehicle while it is in motion, or discharge a passenger at any place other than the curb or pavement edge; (6)  Allow a passenger to consume alcohol, intoxicating substances, or other controlled substances in the vehicle; (7)  Transport a passenger to a destination by a route that is not the safest and most direct, unless the passenger specifically authorizes such alternate or indirect route; (8)  Pick up any additional passengers without the express consent of the original passenger; (9)  Refuse to pick up as a passenger any person of proper deportment when the vehicle is available, or discriminate against any person because of race, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age, or mental or sensory handicap; (10)  Activate the meter when the vehicle is not engaged or fail to activate the meter at the beginning of each trip, unless the trip is made under contract; (11)  Activate equipment indicating the vehicle is engaged when it is not, or fail to activate such equipment when the vehicle is engaged; (12)  Engage in any unfair or deceptive acts or practices. (Code 1989, § 13-161; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002; Ord. No. 523, § 8, 3-3-2003) 
Sec. 48-35. - Enforcement and penalty. (a)  The police department and the code enforcement office shall enforce the regulations contained in this article. (b)  Violations of the provisions of this article shall be punished according to the penalties described in section 1-8. Each separate occurrence shall be deemed a separate offense. (c)  The violation of the provisions of this article by any person, corporation, partnership or other entity may be enjoined by instituting appropriate proceedings for injunction in the courts of competent jurisdiction in this state. Such actions may be maintained notwithstanding that other adequate remedies at law exist. Such actions may be instituted in the name of the city. (d)  Violations of any provision of this article by any permit holder shall be due cause for revocation of any city permit or certificate, after notice and hearing before the city municipal court. (Code 1989, § 13-162; Ord. No. 497, § I, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 48-36. - Miscellaneous.     Nothing in this article shall be deemed to prohibit the charging of a flat rate for trips to and from Hartsfield International Airport, provided that such flat rates are conspicuously posted on the taxicab or set forth on a rate card provided to the customer prior to the trip. (Code 1989, § 13-163; Ord. No. 523, § 9, 3-3-2003)
